isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE / 9200 9300 9400 MODELS BUILT AFTER JANUARY 1, 1995 - CATERPILLAR 3176B/3406E ELECTRONIC ENGINE CONTROLS - 1994 - ELECTRICAL OPERATION - ELECTRONIC CONTROL MODULE (ECM)

svcprocinfo.para: The "Brain" of the 3176B/3406E Electronic Engine Control System is two components working together: the Electronic Control Module (ECM) and the Vehicle Personality Module (VPM). The ECM is mounted on the left side of the engine and the VPM is mounted on the ECM. The ECM is the computer which controls the engine related vehicle functions. The VPM contains the operating instructions (software) including owner selected parameters and other engine information for the ECM to use, controlling how the ECM behaves.

The International engine harness connects to the Caterpillar engine harness using International 40-pin connector (558). Connector (558) connects to Caterpillar 40-pin connector J1. All electronic communication between the International electrical system and the Caterpillar engine control system go through (551)/J1, the International/Caterpillar connection.

svcsubproc.title: Switched Power To The ECM
svcsubproc.para:
Refer to
CIRCUIT DIAGRAMS, Figure 6.07 or Figure 6.10
, for this discussion. With the key switch ON, the ECM receives (12 volt DC) operating power from the vehicle batteries through International engine harness connector (558), terminal 6. The battery power to the ECM is switched ON or OFF by the Run Relay (486), which is energized when the key switch is in the IGN position.

step1.para: Turning the key switch ON applies power from Ignition Adapter (518) to the control coil of the Run Relay (486), causing it to energize. The relay control coil circuit 11-GR goes to ground through (454) Ground Adapter.

With the relay energized battery power from connector (517) B1 Battery Adapter passes through the Normally Open (N.O.) relay contacts (87 to 30) and is sent on circuit 97S to International ECM connector (558) terminal 6. This circuit is protected by 15A fuse F10-A.

svcsubproc.para: Battery power from the B+ BATTERY terminal of the Cranking Motor Solenoid is always applied on circuit 2FL/97F through connector (558) terminal 4 to the ECM. This circuit is protected by a fusible link 2FL.

The ECM uses this power to maintain a portion of memory used for customer trip data accumulators. Disconnecting this circuit does not affect engine operation or factory/customer parameters or logged diagnostic codes. Refer to the Caterpillar Electronic Troubleshooting manual for additional information on this feature.

svcsubproc.title: ECM Inputs And Outputs
svcsubproc.para: The ECM acts as 5V power supply for many Caterpillar and International components used to monitor and control the engine/vehicle systems. The ECM also supplies operating power to the Throttle Position Sensor (253), Low Coolant Sensor (307) and the Engine Fan Relay (315).
The ECM is connected to the International installed switches that communicate with the ECM. The switches are 2-way or 3-way switches and are either ON or OFF.

Refer to
CIRCUIT DIAGRAMS, Figure 6.05 or Figure 6.08
, for this discussion.

The ECM needs to know if the Cruise ON/OFF switch is in the ON or OFF position. To accomplish this the Cruise ON/OFF switch is connected to the ECM with an input circuit 97AE and a "common" or ground circuit 97-GH.

step1.para: Each International installed switch has an "input" circuit that is connected through connector (558) to an assigned ECM terminal. This circuit has 5 volts applied at the ECM terminal.
Each switch is connected to a "common" or ground circuit that is connected through connector (558) terminal 29.

When the Cruise switch is OFF (switch open), the ECM sees 5 volts at ECM terminal 20. Placing the cruise switch to the ON position (switch closed) causes the ECM to see 0 volts (ground voltage will be 0 to 0.5 volts) at terminal 20. The ECM programming has established that the Cruise Control Switch is OFF when it sees 5 volts at connector (558) terminal 20 or cruise is ON when the ECM sees 0 volts at terminal 20.

svcsubproc.para: EXAMPLE: The service brake switch (317) is connected by input circuit 97AL to connector (558) terminal 14. Terminal 14 has a 5-volt signal present. With the brake switch closed (pedal released) the circuit is complete between terminals 14 (input) and 29 (common or ground). This causes the 5 volt signal at terminal 14 to go to zero. This tells the ECM that the service brake switch is closed (pedal released).

This type of circuit is used to communicate switch and some sensor information to the ECM. Some sensors receive a 5 volt signal and return a variable voltage indicating some variable attribute. The ECM also uses 12 volt circuits to enable (energize) relays in the system and supplies 8V power to operate the Throttle Position Sensor.
